entry.title: Define Account Determination for Treasury and Risk Management (TRM)
entry.content:
Purpose

This blog primarily introduces the configuration of Define Account Determination for Treasury and Risk Management (TRM).

If anything regarding TRM account determination has not been clarified in this blog post, please leave a comment and we will try to refine it as soon as possible.

Foundational Knowledge

To fully engage with the content ahead, familiarity with the following foundational concepts is mandatory:

  • Basic knowledge in general ledger accounting, account receivables, account payables, e.g., document types, posting keys, account types (e.g., D - Customers, K - Vendors, S - G/L accounts).
  • Valuation areas in TRM and how they are linked to accounting principles and ledgers.
    • Paying valuation area is linked to the leading ledger.
    • Nonpaying valuation areas are linked to the non-leading ledgers.
  • Update types in TRM and how they are determined from valuation area-independent operational cash flows, valuation area-dependent business transactions (e.g., valuation, accrual, derived business transactions), etc.
  • Account assignment references in TRM and how they are derived.
  • TRM position management and position change categories.
  • Bank account management in cash management.

Configuration activities

Configuration activities (of S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition) or IMG activities (of S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition), and configuration tables will be used in this blog post:

This blog post will be described in the context of public cloud.

TRM account determination logic at a glance

Assess the business requirement

Before starting configuration for account determination, please evaluate the business requirement for posting:

  1. What is the update type for which the posting should be generated? What is the economic essence behind it?
  2. What are the categories for the debit and credit entries of this posting? Is it a posting for position (book value) of the financial instrument, or customer or vendor subledger, or bank clearing account, or profit or loss account (with account assignment required like cost center), or others?
  3. What are the G/L account numbers should be used?
  4. If postings are to be made to vendors or customers, what are the reconciliation accounts or special G/L accounts (derived from reconciliation accounts and special G/L indicators)?

The order of configuration

  1. Define account symbols and specify the posting categories for the account symbols in configuration activity 102121. The available posting categories are:
    • 1 - Position Posting (Book Value) in Position Currency
    • 2 - Subledger Posting in Payment Currency
    • 3 - Bank Posting in Payment Currency
    • 4 - Profit-Related Posting in Position Currency
    • 5 - Profit-Related Posting in Payment Currency
    • 6 - Other G/L Posting in Position Currency
    • 7 - Other G/L Posting in Payment Currency
    • 10 - Currency Swap Between Position Currency / Payment Currency
    • 11- Tax Posting in Payment Currency
  2. Define posting specifications in node ‘Definition of Posting Specifications’ of configuration activity 103014, including document type, posting keys, account symbols, special G/L indicators (optional, only when posting to customer/vendor subledger) for debit and credit entries of the posting specification.
  3. Assign the posting specifications to the update types in node ‘Assignment of Update Types to Posting Specs’ of configuration activity 103014.
  4. Assign the G/L accounts to the account symbols, account assignment references (optional, but usually needed for most cases), valuation areas (optional), currencies (optional) in node ‘Assignment of G/L Accounts to Account symbols’ of configuration activity 103014.

A simple illustration

MM1150- is the update type of interest capitalization from the investment transactions of money market. MM1150- is assigned with the posting specification 13700, which can be seen from the node ‘Assignment of Update Types to Posting Specs’ of configuration activity 103014.

In the node ‘Definition of Posting Specifications’ of configuration activity 103014, check the posting specification 13700:

  • Document type: SA
  • Debit entry: posting key 40, account symbol 1 (posting category: 1 - Position Posting (Book Value) in Position Currency)
  • Debit entry: posting key 50, account symbol 4.1.3 (4 - Profit-Related Posting in Position Currency)

The account symbols are created and their posting categories are specified in configuration activity 102121:

In the node ‘Assignment of G/L Accounts to Account symbols’ of configuration activity 103014:

  • Assign G/L account 18030000 (Long Term Investments, Unaffiliated(TRM)) to account symbol 1 and account assignment reference 201100000000.
  • Assign G/L account 70200000 (Interest Income, Unaffiliated(TRM)) to account symbol 4.1.1 and account assignment reference 201100000000.

Posting result: when running TBB1/TPM10 for the interest capitalization flow using update type MM1150- from an investment money market transaction with account assignment reference 201100000000, the posting journal entry would be debiting 18030000 and crediting 70200000.

Position posting (book value) in position currency

To post to the financial assets or liabilities reflected in the position accounts of the financial instruments, please use an account symbol with posting category 1 - Position Posting (Book Value) in Position Currency.

The position accounts of the financial instruments include (but are not limited to) the long/short term investment or debt arising from debt instruments (e.g., deposits, CDs, loans, bonds, ABS/MBS), equity investments (e.g., stock, shareholding), fund investments, derivative assets or liabilities from derivative financial instruments (e.g., forwards, options, swaps), receivables or payables arising from trade finance contracts like letter of credit, regardless of how the G/L accounts of positions are named in your chart of accounts.

Usually, if an account symbol with posting category 1 is involved in an update type where the position change category cannot be automatically determined, especially for the update type mapped to an operational cash flow from financial transactions or securities account management, the update type should be assigned with a proper position change category in the configuration activity 102097 - Set Effects of Update Types on Position Components, to ensure that the effects on position changes in TRM position management and position accounts postings are consistent.

Examples:

Bank clearing account or Payment request clearing account

This section elaborates the usage of posting category 3 - Bank Posting in Payment Currency. Let’s have a look at the following example:

In configuration activity 102121 - Define Account Symbols, the account symbol 3 “Bank clearing” is defined with posting category 3.

In the node ‘Assignment of G/L Accounts to Account symbols’ of configuration activity 103014, in the field “G/L account”, the account mask “+++++++080” is assigned to the account symbol 3.

The posting spec 11100 is assigned to update type MM1100- (principal increase of investment transaction of money market). Posting spec 11100 credits account symbol 3.

Create an investment transaction for interest rate instrument. In the tab Payment Details, ‘Without’ is selected for “Payment Request” option of direction “outflow”, the house bank is DEBK1 and account ID is DEAC1.

In tab Cash Flow, the field “Payment Request” is empty for the principal increase flow as of 22.12.2025 (flow type 1100, direction ‘outflow’, update type MM1100-).

Run TBB1/TPM10 as of 22.12.2025. Check posting log:

The posting of MM1100- credits G/L account 0011001080.

How is 0011001080 determined?

System first finds out the G/L account of house bank DEBK1 and account ID DEAC1 of company code 1010, it is 0011001000 (the bank main account).

System them applies account mask +++++++080 (the “G/L account” assigned to account symbol 3) to the bank main account 0011001000:

  • The first 7digits of the bank main account 0011001000—0011001—are retained, as each "+" in the mask "+++++++080" indicates a character to be preserved.
  • The last 3 digits of the bank main account 0011001000 are replaced with the fixed characters "080" from the mask "+++++++080".
  • Combining 0011001 and 080 results in the bank sub-account (bank clearing account) 0011001080, which is then used for posting.

Let’s create another investment transaction for interest rate instrument. In the tab Payment Details, ‘With’ is selected for “Payment Request” option of direction “outflow”, the house bank is DEBK1 and account ID is DEAC1, the payer/payee and its partner bank (which are required in payment request) are also specified in the sub-area “Payment”.

In tab Cash Flow, the field “payment request” is “X” for the principal increase flow as of 22.12.2025 (flow type 1100, direction ‘outflow’, update type MM1100-).

Run TBB1/TPM10 as of 22.12.2025. Check posting log:

Now, the posting of MM1100- credits G/L account 21900000 (Payment Request Clearing Account (TRM)).

How is 21900000 determined?

When the “payment request” is ‘X’, system abandons the use of the bank clearing account. Instead, system retrieves the account maintained in configuration activity 105589 - Define Clearing Accounts for Cross-Country/Region Bank Account Transfers.

In TBB1, you can also check the payment log, in which you can find the payment request number.

Afterwards, please use the app Automatic Payment Transactions for Payment Request (transaction F111) to process the payment request, create accounting document debiting 21900000 and crediting bank clearing account (determined by payment program instead of TRM), and create the payment medium if necessary. The detailed process is not elaborated herein.

Summary:

  • For a payment-related flow where the relevant account symbol uses posting category 3, whether a bank clearing account or a payment request clearing account is called depends on whether its payment details use with or without payment request.
    • Without payment request: bank clearing account is determined by applying the account mask (e.g., “+++++++080” which is specified in configuration activity 103014’s "Assignment of G/L Accounts to Account Symbols" node) to the bank main account.
    • With payment request: payment request clearing account is called. Payment request clearing account is specified in the configuration activity 105589.
  • Bank clearing account (without payment request) is typically applicable to bank-initiated payments (e.g., most incoming payments), and its open items should subsequently be reconciled with bank statement items.
  • Payment requests are typically applicable to corporate-initiated payment scenarios, where the company should “inform” the bank to process the payment (e.g., via a payment medium sent to the bank).

Paying/Nonpaying valuation areas and Postings to customers or vendors

You may already aware that different posting specifications can be assigned to the same update type in the node ‘Assignment of Update Types to Posting Specs’ of configuration activity 103014, differentiated by the second column “Payment Transaction” (hereinafter referred to as “P”) and third column “Posted in Pay. VA”. For example:

  • 11100 is assigned to MM1100- with “P” unselected and “Not Specified” specified for “Posted in Pay. VA”.
  • 71100 is assigned to MM1100- with “P” selected and “Paying Valuation Areas” specified for “Posted in Pay. VA”.
  • 81100 is assigned to MM1100- with “P” selected and “Nonpaying Valuation Areas” specified for “Posted in Pay. VA”.

If “P” is selected, it means the intention is to generate posting to customer or vendor subledger (FI-AR / FI-AP). In this example, the purposes of 71100 and 81100 are to post to vendor in credit side.

The posting spec 11100 assigned to MM1100- with “P” unselected has been explained in above section “Bank clearing account or Payment request clearing account”, in which the credit entry is posted to bank clearing account or payment request clearing account, instead of vendor or customer.

We will elaborate details of posting specs 71100 and 81100 in current section:

  • 71100 is used for the postings in paying valuation area.
    • Credit entry’s account symbol is V.0 in this example, this account symbol must use posting category 2 - Subledger Posting in Payment Currency.
    • Credit entry’s posting key must be relevant to account type D (customer) or K (vendor). In this example, the posting key 34 is used, 34 is a posting key for account type K.
  • 81100 is used for the postings in nonpaying valuation areas.
    • Credit entry’s account symbol is V.0 in this example, this account symbol must use posting category 2 - Subledger Posting in Payment Currency.
    • Credit entry’s posting key must be relevant to account type S (G/L accounts), instead of account type D or K. In this example, the posting key 50 is used.

Let’s use the following example to illustrate the outcome of this configuration of 71100 and 81100.

Create an investment transaction for interest rate instrument. In the tab Payment Details, ‘to customer’ is selected for “Posting” option of direction “outflow”, which means for outflows, the postings should post to customer or vendor. Although it is called “to customer”, it can also post to vendor (actually it is controlled by posting key). In this example, because posting key 34 is used, and posting key 34 is relevant to account type K, so it posts to vendor instead of customer.

In tab Cash Flow, the field “Payment Transaction” is “X” (because ‘to customer’ is selected in Payment Details) for the principal increase flow as of 22.12.2025 (flow type 1100, direction ‘outflow’, update type MM1100-), indicating that it should post to customer or vendor. And the business partner entered in the field Payer/Payee (10537001 in this example) in sub-area “Payment” should be the customer or vendor (vendor in this example).

Run TBB1/TPM10 as of 22.12.2025 for all valuation areas (paying and nonpaying valuation areas). Check posting log:

1100- cash flow is “Payment Transaction” = “X” and DE0 is the paying valuation area, therefore, for the posting in DE0, MM1100- uses the posting spec 71100 which is assigned to MM1100- with “P” selected and “Paying Valuation Areas” specified for “Posted in Pay. VA” in the configuration.

Posting spec 71100 uses the posting key 34 which is for vendor (account type K), so system knows that it should post to the vendor 10537001 (the business partner entered in the field Payer/Payee of payment details in the transaction). In above screen-shot of posting log, the G/L account of posting key 34 is empty (it is not a bug!), this is because the TRM accounting interface passes on the vendor account 10537001 to FI directly, and FI determines the reconciliation account from the vendor master data of 10537001. Checking the line item of the journal entry, you will see it credits the vendor 10537001, and its reconciliation account 21100000 is also there in the line item. To ensure successful posting, the business partner 10537001 must be extended to the BP role FLVN00 (FI supplier) and the reconciliation account of vendor 10537001 must be maintained in advance.

1100- cash flow is “Payment Transaction” = “X” and 002 and 003 are the nonpaying valuation area, therefore, for postings in 002 and 003, MM1100- uses the posting spec 81100 which is assigned to MM1100- with “P” selected and “Nonpaying Valuation Areas” specified for “Posted in Pay. VA” in the configuration.

81100 uses the posting key 50 which is for account type S, and from the screen-shot of TRM posting log, you already see the reconciliation account 21100000 has been determined in TRM.

How does TRM determine reconciliation account 21100000 for nonpaying valuation areas:

  • 81100 uses the account symbol V.0 with posting category 2, so TRM knows it should post to vendor or customer.
  • TRM checks the corresponding posting spec 71100 used in the paying valuation area, 71100 uses posting key 34 for account symbol V.0, posting key 34 indicates that the posting is done to vendor.
  • Then TRM determines that the 81100 should also post to vendor’s reconciliation account.
  • TRM finds out the reconciliation account 21100000 from the vendor master data of 10537001 in corresponding company code.
  • 81100 directly posts to 21100000 using posting key 50, that means, 211000000 is provided in the TRM accounting interface to FI, and FI uses it for posting directly.

Therefore, from an accounting perspective, the credit postings in all valuation areas are recorded in reconciliation account 21100000 of vendor 10537001, even though the paying and nonpaying valuation areas differ in their realization methods.

A common FAQ is why different posting keys must be used for customer and vendor postings in paying versus nonpaying valuation areas for the same update type. In other modules (e.g., FI-AR, FI-AP), customer and vendor postings can be posted simultaneously in all ledgers (both leading and non-leading) without the need to specify a ledger group—meaning posting keys for account types D and K are valid for journals across all ledgers. By contrast, TRM always executes valuation area-dependent postings, which means postings from a paying valuation area are posted exclusively to the ledger group associated with the leading ledger, while those from a nonpaying valuation area are posted exclusively to the ledger group associated with the corresponding non-leading ledger. For customer and vendor postings in the leading ledger, posting keys for account types D and K are to be used (enabling open item management and subsequent clearing); however, for postings exclusive to non-leading ledgers, such posting keys are not permitted due to FI module design. This is why it is necessary to use posting keys 40 and 50 (or other account type S posting keys) for customer and vendor postings originating from nonpaying valuation areas.

Summary and Additional notes:

  • When posting category 2 is used, whether the posting is made to vendor or customer is decided by the account type of the posting key specified in the posting spec assigned to the update type with “P” selected and “Paying Valuation Areas” specified for “Posted in Pay. VA”.
    • If the posting key is for account type D (typically posting keys 01~19), it is posting to customer.
    • If the posting key is for account type K (typically posting keys 21~39), it is posting to vendor.
    • Paying valuation area: TRM directly passes on the posting key and business partner (payer/payee) to FI, and FI will determine it is posting to customer or vendor based on the account type of posting key.
    • Nonpaying valuation area: TRM determines it is customer or vendor based on the posting key of the corresponding posting spec used in paying valuation area, retrieves the reconciliation account of customer or vendor, and passes on the reconciliation account to FI for posting directly.
  • An account symbol with posting category 2 should be used exclusively with posting keys for either vendors or customers (not both) across all posting specifications. Improper configuration will trigger error message TPM_TRAC1 040 ("Cannot determine account type for account symbol V.0") in TBB1/TPM10.
    • Proper configuration examples:
      • In all posting specs, account symbol V.0 is only associated with posting keys for account type K (typically 21~39).
      • In all posting specs, account symbol V.0 is only associated with posting keys for account type D (typically 01~19).
    • Improper configuration example:
      • In some posting specs, account symbol V.0 is associated with posting keys for account type K (typically 21~39); whereas there are some other posting specs in which account symbol V.0 is associated with posting keys for account type D (typically 01~19).
  • The document type used for paying valuation area related posting spec should allow postings to account type D, if any account symbol in the posting spec uses posting category 2 and the posting key is for account type D (typically 01~19).
  • The document type used for paying valuation area related posting spec should allow postings to account type K, if any account symbol in the posting spec uses posting category 2 and the posting key is for account type K (typically 21~39).
  • Postings to special G/L accounts are also possible. To achieve it, please configure posting specifications like below:
    • Posting spec of paying valuation area:
      • If the need is to post to customer:
        • Use posting key 09 (debit) or 19 (credit)
        • Specify a proper and available Special G/L indicator for customer (account type D)
      • Or, if the need is to post to vendor:
        • Use posting key 29 (debit) or 39 (credit)
        • Specify a proper and available Special G/L indicator for vendor (account type K)
    • Posting spec of nonpaying valuation areas:
      • Use posting key 40 (debit) or 50 (credit) for customer or vendor
      • Specify the same Special G/L Indicator as that used in the corresponding posting spec for the paying valuation area.
    • The mapping of special G/L accounts to reconciliation accounts should already be configured in FI for the special G/L indicators of account type D or K.
    • Account determination logic:
      • Paying valuation area: similar to reconciliation account posting logic. TRM passes on the vendor/customer account (payer/payee) and special G/L indicator to FI via accounting interface, FI will use the vendor/customer account for posting directly, and FI will determine it’s vendor or customer from the account type of posting key and found out the special G/L account.
      • Nonpaying valuation areas: also similar to reconciliation account determination. TRM checks the posting keys of corresponding posting spec of paying valuation area, determines it is for vendor (posting key 29/39) or customer (posting key 09/19), finds out the reconciliation account, and determines the special G/L account of the reconciliation account and the special G/L indicator of account type D or K, passes on the special G/L account to FI posting directly.
  • The reconciliation account or special G/L account is used for vendor or customer related postings, and they are automatically determined (by FI for paying VA, or by TRM for nonpaying VAs), therefore, it is not necessary to assign and please do NOT assign any G/L accounts to account symbols with posting category 2 in node ‘Assignment of G/L Accounts to Account symbols’ of configuration activity 103014.
  • There is a sub-node “Assignment of Update Types to Posting Specs” under node “Valuation Areas” (table TRAC_DFTRULE2) in configuration activity 103014. TRAC_DFTRULE2 is used to assign different posting specs for the same update type in different valuation areas or company codes. Examples of application scenarios:
    • Different nonpaying valuation areas should use different posting specs for the same update type.
    • Different company codes should use different posting specs for the same update type in the same valuation area.
  • When considered alongside tables TRAC_DFTRULE1 (1st-level node: "Assignment of Update Types to Posting Specifications" in configuration activity 103014) and TRAC_DFTRULE2, the logic for determining the posting specification of an update type in a valuation area is as follows:
  • If "To Customer" is selected in the Payment Details (where the field "Payment Transaction" is set to "X" for cash flow) in a transaction, a posting spec must be assigned to the corresponding update type—with "P" (Payment Transaction) selected—in TRAC_DFTRULE1 or TRAC_DFTRULE2 in configuration activity 103014. If this is not the case, the system cannot determine the posting spec and will issue an error message when executing TBB1/TPM10.

Profit-related postings

The posting category 4 - Profit-Related Posting in Position Currency or 5 - Profit-Related Posting in Payment Currency should be used for the account symbols assigned with the profit or loss G/L accounts which are set up as primary cost elements (cost element category 1 - Primary costs).

The primary cost element needs account assignments (e.g., cost center) during posting. Only with posting category 4 or 5, the account assignments in treasury position indicator will be passed on to accounting document line items.

A frequently seen issue: the cost center appears in the position indicator of a treasury transaction (via any workable means mentioned in blog post Account Assignment in TRM Financial Transactions - Cost Center). However, this cost center is not used for postings done by TBB1 or TPM10, and error message like “account assignment can’t be determined for cost element” is raised. The cause could be that the relevant account symbols (assigned with cost element in node “Assignment of G/L Accounts to Account symbols”) doesn’t use posting category 4 or 5.

Currency swap between position currency and payment currency

The usage of posting category 10 - Currency Swap Between Position Currency / Payment Currency is special. In this example, the account symbol 9.1.4 uses posting category 10.

Account symbol 9.1.4 is not used in any posting specs.

A technical clearing account 22549000 is assigned to account symbol 9.1.4.

In the names of posting categories, you always see “…in payment currency” or “…in position currency”, these indicate which currency is the transaction currency in accounting documents—payment currency or position currency.

When a posting spec involves two account symbols posted in different currencies—one is in payment currency and the other is in position currency, then the account 22549000 will be automatically involved.

For example, the posting spec 11100 is assigned to update type MM1902- (which is capitalized charges). 11100 debits with account symbol 1 (posting in position currency) and credits with account symbol 3 (posting in payment currency).

Now assume the position currency of the transaction if USD (the principal and interest are paid in USD), however, the charge MM1902- is paid in EUR. Check the posting log for MM1902-:

MM1902- credits bank clearing account in the transaction currency EUR (=payment currency of this flow), but its debit side recognizes position which is posted in transaction currency USD (=position currency of this transaction). In this case, two accounting documents are created for MM1902-:

  • One uses transaction currency USD, debits position account and credits technical clearing account 22549000;
  • The other uses the transaction currency EUR, debits technical clearing account 22549000 and credits bank clearing account.

The technical clearing account 22549000 is involved in two documents, and it has identical amounts in valuation currency within two accounting documents.

This kind of handling is necessary because only one single transaction currency is allowed in one accounting document (design of FI).

entry.title: SAP ERP公有云2602版本中国本地化亮点解析：增值税发票管理与财务功能优化
entry.content:
SAP ERP公有云2602版本为中国用户带来了一系列实用的本地化功能优化，这些更新旨在帮助企业更好地满足中国税务合规要求，提升财务管理效率。本文将详细介绍以下更新内容：

  • 基于SAP Document and Reporting Compliance的更新
    • 中国增值税发票管理更新
    • 中国现金流量表更新
    • 电子凭证会计数据标准解决方案更新
  • 中国现金流量表（IDCNCASH）旧方案迭代更新

 

中国增值税发票管理(基于SAP Document and Reporting Compliance)更新

销项增值税发票管理功能更新- SAP金税接口（GTI）新增配置：计费折扣税

在大多数客户系统中，计费折扣税(Tax Discount Amount，简称TDA)通常不在SAP销售与分销(SD)模块中计算。为了在中国增值税发票中准确体现这一金额，SAP金税接口(GTI)在设计之初采用了自行计算的方式。

简而言之，GTI一直采用以下方式计算TDA:

  • 从SD获取不含税额(Net Value)
  • 获取税额(Tax Amount)
  • 获取折扣金额(Discount Amount) 
  • 在GTI中独立计算税收折扣金额(TDA)

在某些特殊场景下，为确保最终税额的准确性，GTI会调整含税总额(Gross Amount)，以确保在扣除折扣后的税额在金税系统和财务中是一致的。这导致SAP销售订单与GTI开具发票上的含税总额出现差异，给业务用户的日常工作带来困扰。

从CE2602版本开始，SAP GTI提供了标准配置选项，允许用户直接从SD模块获取税收折扣金额，而非在GTI中重新计算。

具体步骤：

  1. 使用新增标准配置项定义TDA金额设置：用户在配置“金税流程的缺省值” - “计费折扣税”中，输入在SD中定义的条件类型Condition Type ID。

     图1：新增“计费折扣税“金额设置

  2. 设置折扣金额（Discount Amount）属性：用户还需在Define GTI Tax Invoice Keys再次确认‘Price Mode’配置，以保证GTI计算正确：
    • 如果客户在SD为折扣金额的定价条件设置是含税，那么金税中Price Mode需选择‘Discount Amount with VAT’；
    • 如果客户在SD为折扣金额的定价条件设置是不含税，那么金税中Price Mode需选择‘Discount Amount without VAT’；

通过这种方式，这一改进有效解决了数据不一致的问题，减少因系统差异导致的业务混乱，让业务流程更加顺畅。

 

销项增值税发票管理功能更新 – “备注”延长至630个字符

在关于全面数字化电子发票（FDEI）使用常见问题清单的更新公告中，提到一项变更涉及 “备注”字段的字符长度限制，主要变化是从之前的230个字符延长至630个字符。同时，字符计数方法也进行了更新：一个汉字计为三个字符，而每个数字和英文字母计为一个字符。

图2: 支持正常读写超过230个字符的备注字段

这次调整意味着企业在开具电子发票时，可以在备注栏填写更详细的交易信息。例如，合同编号、项目名称、特殊说明等内容都能更完整地记录，减少了因字数限制而需要简化描述的困扰。

使用FDEI的纳税人，建议征询当地税务机关获取最新的FDEI的常见问题清单。

欢迎访问SAP Regulatory Change Manager了解该法律变更及SAP产品功能变更的更多信息。

 

销项增值税发票管理功能更新 – “行项目限制”扩展至2000行

开具全电发票的模版中，对“发票明细行数“的最新要求（填表说明）是：超过2000行后可能会导致系统异常无法开具发票。

从CE2602起，使用中国增值税发票管理来开具全面数字化电子发票（FDEI）的企业，可以在Define GTI Tax Invoice Keys中配置“行项目限制”为2000，系统会自动拆分超过2000行限制的电子发票。

图3: 设置行项目限制为2000

引入这个新配置，可使生成的发票文件不超过税局服务器承载能力，符合限制要求，确保生成的发票文件都能成功上传。

欢迎访问SAP Regulatory Change Manager了解该法律变更及SAP产品功能变更的更多信息。

 

进项增值税发票管理功能更新 – 发票入账标识

在金税系统的全电发票流程中，发票入账标识是一项重要的新功能。简单来说，当买方将全电发票标记为"已入账"后，卖方就无法单方面撤销该发票了。如果卖方确实需要撤销，必须先获得买方的批准才能操作。

这项功能的核心目的是防止供应商随意撤销发票，保护买方的权益。需要特别注意的是，这里的"入账"概念与SAP系统中的财务凭证过账是两回事——前者是税务层面的标识，后者是企业内部的财务处理。

从CE2602起，在进项增值税发票管理解决方案中，我们新增“同步发票入账”流程，在业务系统和金税系统之间同步发票入账信息。

图4: 显示发票入账状态

具体步骤：

  1. 对于非直连场景：

用户首先在金税系统中维护进项增值税发票的入账信息。然后，用户在SAP业务系统中，使用“管理增值税进项发票”应用，选择新按钮“同步发票入账”，更新入账期间、入账类型、发票入账同步日期，并指定是否入账发票以保持信息同步。

 图5: 非直连场景下的同步发票入账

2. 对于直连场景：

  • 用户使用“管理增值税进项发票”应用，选择新按钮“同步发票入账”，维护入账期间、入账类型并通过 API 将数据发送到金税系统以完成入账。

 图6: 直连场景下的同步发票入账

  • 然后，处理结果会从金税系统写回SAP业务系统。

 图7: 金税系统处理结果写回SAP

目前系统支持以下发票入账类型（与金税系统保持一致）：

  • 02：入账（企业所得税税前扣除）
  • 03：入账（企业所得税不扣除）
  • 04：入账（个人所得税经营所得税前扣除）
  • 05：入账（个人所得税经营所得不扣除）
  • 06：入账撤销

已入账状态同步至税局后，表示买方已确认发票详情，并准备将其用于会计和税务目的。如果需要撤销已入账的发票，卖方必须获得买方的批准。这意味着在发票被标记为“已入账”后，任何更改都需要双方的知情和同意。

引入发票入账信息管理这一新流程，为交易增加了安全性，确保发票信息的不可变性，同时保护买方的利益。

 

进项增值税发票管理功能更新 – 发票常规信息的新增字段

为进一步完善进项发票的同步信息，从CE2602起，我们还添加了以下常规信息字段：

 图8: 常规信息新增字段

  • （新增）发票风险等级：
    • 01：正常
    • 02：异常凭证
    • 03：疑似异常凭证

请注意，管理进项增值税申报应用中不提供风险级别为异常的发票。

  • （新增）特定要素类型：
    • 01, 成品油
    • 02, 稀土
    • 03, 建筑服务
    • 04, 货物运输服务
    • 05, 不动产销售服务
    • 06, 不动产经营租赁服务
    • 07, 代收车船税
    • 08, 通行费
    • 09, 旅客运输服务
    • 10, 医疗服务（住院）
    • 11, 医疗服务（门诊）
    • 12, 自产农产品销售
    • 13, 拖拉机和联合收割机
    • 14, 机动车
    • 15, 二手车
    • 16, 农产品收购
    • 17, 光伏收购
    • 18, 卷烟
    • 20, 农产品
  • （新增）蓝字发票号码
  • （增强）用途：
    • 0：未使用
    • 1：已申请抵扣
    • 2: 已申请退税
    • 3: 已申请代办退税
    • 4: 已勾选不抵扣（历史数据）
    • 5: 已申请代办退税（历史数据）
    • 6: 已申请不抵扣
    • 7: 内销转出口
    • 8: 出口转内销
    • 9: 准予退税
    • 10: 不予退税
    • 11: 冬奥退税

 

中国现金流量表(基于SAP Document and Reporting Compliance)更新

基于SAP Document and Reporting Compliance的中国现金流量表（报表ID:CN_CASHFLOW_N）和SAP Group Reporting 集团报表解决方案，都使用交易类型Transaction Type（ACDOCA- RMVCT）字段作为手动判断来补充自动确定逻辑。然而，这导致了在同一交易中需要使用两种不同的交易类型用于出具单体财务报表和合并报表，从而引发财务报告过程中字段使用冲突。

基于SAP Document and Reporting Compliance的中国现金流量表（报表ID:CN_CASHFLOW_N），此前在定义限制参数时，仅支持交易类型 Transaction Type、功能范围 Functional Area和税码Tax Code。

从CE2602起，基于SAP Document and Reporting Compliance的中国现金流量表将支持灵活的自定义限制参数，包括ACDOCA表中SAP标准字段以及自定义字段作为限制参数，以替代交易类型，从而解决了上述字段使用冲突的问题。

 图9：支持用户定义更多限制参数（除交易类型、功区域和税码之外）：

 图10：支持客户使用自定义字段用于限制参数

通过引入更灵活的参数定义，企业可以更好地适应其特定的财务报告需求。这不仅简化了报告流程，还减少了由于交易类型冲突而导致的错误和不一致性。最终，这将提高财务报告的准确性和效率，使企业能够更好地做出战略决策。

 

电子凭证会计数据标准 解决方案(基于SAP Document and Reporting Compliance)更新

由中华人民共和国财政部机九部门联合制定的《电子凭证会计数据标准》为电子凭证会计信息化处理提供了统一的技术规范和结构化数据标准，支持包含结构化数据的电子凭证用于接收、报销、入账、归档等全流程各环节。

从CE2602起，SAP中国本地化团队将通过分阶段的方式，发布符合《电子凭证会计数据标准》的本地化新功能，以及对现有财务本地化方案的增强。

在CE2602版本中，用户可通过SAP Document and Reporting Compliance新增的“中国会计核算信息的结构化数据文件（会计核算数据标准）“报表类别，将入账相关的信息按照《电子凭证会计数据标准》生成XBRL 电子文件，即入账信息结构化数据文件；支持的电子凭证类型包括：

  • 全面数字化的电子发票（不包含铁路电子客票，航空运输电子客票行程单）
  • 增值税电子发票

（以上均包含专用发票及普通发票）

 图11：新增报表类别支持

具体步骤：

  1. 使用“运行法定报表-中国总账报表“应用，输入相应报表期间、报表实体等信息后，运行并生成并管理入账信息结构化文件（XBRL文件）：

 图12：运行并生成入账信息结构化文件（XBRL文件）

2. 运行成功后，用户可查看并下载入账信息结构化文件（XBRL文件），示例如下：

 图13：入账信息结构化文件（XBRL文件）示例

 

SAP本地化团队将陆续发布更多本地化功能，以支持客户实现《电子凭证会计数据标准》中电子凭证的接收、报销、入账、归档等全流程各环节，敬请期待。

欢迎访问SAP Regulatory Change Manager了解该法律变更及SAP产品功能变更的更多信息。

 

中国现金流量表（IDCNCASH）旧方案迭代更新

中国现金流量表方案经历了多个阶段的发展，从最初的基于旧科目抵销确定方案的GUI报表（IDCNCASH），到基于SAP Document and Reporting Compliance的新方案（CN_CASHFLOW_N）。旧方案IDCNCASH采用了较为传统的技术架构，与SAP最新的平台和UI技术脱节，存在性能优化空间有限的问题。而新方案则充分利用了SAP Document and Reporting Compliance的优势，提供了更高效的性能和更丰富的功能。

以下是新旧方案多维度对比：

  • 在性能方面，旧方案存在超时dump的问题，而新方案则利用HANA内存数据库的卓越设计，性能优越
  • 在多币种支持方面，新方案能够支持所有分配给公司代码和账套的货币类型，而旧方案仅支持有限的几种货币类型
  • 在数据源方面，新方案直接从核心财务模块的ACDOCA表取数，与其他相关报表高度一致，而旧方案的数据源与核心财务模块不一致

根据SAP 产品战略政策和产品规划，旧中国现金流量表（IDCNCASH）已进入迭代窗口。因此从CE2602起，我们正式启动旧中国现金流量表（IDCNCASH）的迭代工作。建议所有使用旧方案的客户，尽快迁移到基于SAP Document and Reporting Compliance的新现金流量表方案。为了帮助客户顺利完成迁移，SAP本地化团队为客户准备了详细的实施手册和视频教程：

  • 基于抵销科目确定方案的中国新本地化现金流量表白皮书
  •  视频教程

 

从CE2602 开始，支持新旧方案的切换操作：

1. 用户可通过旧方案中的弹窗，或“新版本“开关按钮，切换至新方案。

 图14：旧方案内新增弹窗并支持跳转至新方案

 

2. 切换至新方案后，用户可使用“新版本“开关按钮切换回旧方案；欢迎用户在”提供反馈“中，提出新方案使用过程中的问题或建议。

entry.title: Enterprise Portfolio and Project Management in SAP Cloud ERP 2602
entry.content:
Welcome to your one-stop shop to learn and share knowledge about SAP's ready-to-run public cloud ERP software solution.  

SAP Cloud ERP is part of SAP Business Suite that brings AI, data, and applications together into a fully integrated system. This community is open for anyone in the Cloud ERP ecosystem–customers, partners, and SAP experts.  

 

In this blog post I’d like to outline the innovations for SAP Cloud ERP 2602 in the area of Enterprise Portfolio and Project Management. These are the topics that are covered:

  • Enhanced integration of project plan information with SAP Cloud ERP (6JN) 
  • Project staffing view for resource managers (6JO) 
  • Allowing contingent workers (cost center procured) to record time on enterprise projects (1NT, 1Q4) 
  • Automatic removal of billing block for sales order billing plans (1NT) 
  • Joule as project assistant (beta), planned to be available mid-March
  • Further innovations

 

Check out my video to get a glimpse of the new features:

 

In today's fast-paced business environment, running projects efficiently, on time, and on budget is more critical than ever. This release is packed with features designed to bring more intelligence, automation, and transparency to your projects, ultimately driving significant business value. We’ve focused on streamlining processes, enhancing integration, and even giving you a glimpse into the future with AI-powered assistance.

Let's dive into the highlights that will help you unlock new levels of project success.

 

Enhancements in SAP Project and Resource Management

 

Enhanced integration of project plan information with SAP Cloud ERP

In complex projects spanning engineering, manufacturing, and services, a major challenge is keeping project execution plans in sync with core financial and logistical data. A delay in a design phase, for example, has a direct impact on procurement timelines and billing dates. If this information isn't shared instantly between the project planning tool and the core ERP, decisions are made based on outdated information. To solve this, our 2602 release supercharges the integration between SAP Project and Resource Management, our solution on the SAP Business Technology Platform, and SAP Cloud ERP. Now, when a project manager adjusts a project plan – such as extending a phase – the system automatically synchronizes these date changes with the core ERP in real time.

This direct synchronization ensures that your financial, commercial, and logistical data within SAP Cloud ERP always reflects the most current project reality, empowering you to make reliable decisions based on a single source of truth. By automating the update process, you eliminate the need for project teams to manually replicate date changes across systems, which significantly reduces administrative effort and minimizes the risk of human error. This tight integration also lays the groundwork for faster billing cycles, as milestone completions in the project plan can now directly trigger commercial processes in the core system.

 

Figure 1: Improved integration of project plan information between SAP Cloud ERP and SAP Project and Resource Management, enables better decision-making in projects through reliable, up-to-date project plan information.

 

Project staffing view for resource managers

Resource managers are constantly juggling demands from multiple projects, and gaining a clear, consolidated overview of the staffing situation for a specific project can be a fragmented and time-consuming process. To address this pain point, we are introducing a brand-new SAP Fiori app called “Manage Request Assignments”. This powerful application is designed specifically for resource managers, providing a single, project-centric view of all resource requests. It shows at a glance which roles have been fully staffed, which are partially staffed, and which are still open, eliminating the need to dig through multiple screens and reports.

This new application provides resource managers with unprecedented transparency into the staffing health of any project, allowing them to instantly identify bottlenecks and open demands without extensive research. Having all the necessary information in one place, with direct navigation to take action, streamlines the workflow and dramatically reduces the time it takes to staff open requests and get the right people on the right tasks. Ultimately, a clear, holistic overview empowers resource managers to more effectively optimize staffing within a single project or re-allocate experts across multiple projects, ensuring your most valuable resources are deployed with maximum impact.

 

Figure 2: The “Manage Request Assignments” application allows users to efficiently view the resource request and assignment details at a project level.

 

Other Innovations in SAP Project and Resource Management

Additional enhancements introduced in SAP Project and Resource Management. For example:

  • Technical user flow coverage (client credential flow) for some APIs
  • Use of actual dates in scheduling
  • Consideration of working and none working days in scheduling
  • Ability to block certain file types during file upload
  • Additional details for tasks and collaboration project

For a complete list and more details please take a look into the What's new document for SAP Project and Resource Management

 

 

Enhancements in Enterprise Portfolio and Project Management

 

Allowing contingent workers (cost center procured) to record time on enterprise projects

Modern project teams are a dynamic blend of internal employees and external contingent workers. A significant process gap existed for contingent workers who were procured via a cost center, as they couldn't use the standard “My Timesheet” application to record time against enterprise projects. This made it difficult to get a complete and timely picture of all labor hours and costs. With the 2602 release, we have closed this gap. Now, these contingent workers can use the very same “My Timesheet” application as internal employees to record their time against the projects they are staffed on, creating a unified experience for the entire team.

This enhancement delivers a unified and simplified process where all project resources, regardless of their employment type, use a single application for time recording, which improves the user experience. You can now capture every hour worked against your project demands in one central place, providing a more accurate and timely view of total project costs and progress. Furthermore, the system automates the creation of the corresponding service entry sheet and goods receipt upon timesheet approval, significantly reducing administrative overhead and ensuring your suppliers are paid accurately and on time.

Figure 3: Project-based and cost center-based contingent workers can record time seamlessly in the “Manage My Timesheet” application, ensuring consistent tracking and better visibility across all engagement types.

 

Automatic removal of billing block for sales order billing plans

Milestone billing is a fantastic way to align payments with project progress, but it has often been hampered by a manual step. Once a milestone was achieved, someone had to go into the sales order and manually remove the billing block to make that item available for invoicing, a delay that directly impacts cash flow. We have now fully automated this process. Building on a feature from our last release, the system now automatically removes the billing block from the corresponding billing plan item in the related sales order the moment a project manager confirms the completion of that milestone in the project.

By completely automating this process, you eliminate the manual hand-off and inherent delays, allowing you to invoice your customers the very moment a milestone is contractually met. This directly accelerates your order-to-cash cycle and improves cash flow. This automation also removes a tedious and error-prone manual task, freeing up your project controllers and sales administrators to focus their expertise on more strategic, value-added activities. The risk of human error is entirely eliminated, leading to a smoother, more reliable, and more accurate billing process from end to end.

 

Figure 4: For sales order billing plan items which are created based on enterprise project or WBS element milestones, the billing block is automatically removed when the related milestone is completed.

 

Joule as project assistant (beta), planned to be available mid-March

Setting up a new project can be a complex and time-consuming task, often requiring project managers to navigate between three or four different applications to define the scope, staff resources, and release the project for time recording. We are incredibly excited to give you a preview of how we are solving this with the future of project management: the Joule Project Assistant. This is our generative AI copilot, and we are starting with a beta agent designed to radically simplify the creation of internal projects. Instead of clicking through multiple screens, a project manager can simply ask Joule in natural language, e.g. "Create a new pre-sales project for the 'Rising Star' initiative, starting next week and lasting for one month.". Joule can then propose a template, adjust dates, staff the project, and release it – all within a single, conversational session.

This AI-powered assistant promises dramatic efficiency gains, condensing a multi-application process into a single, swift conversation that saves significant time and effort for your project managers. The intuitive, conversational nature of Joule makes project creation accessible to everyone, drastically reducing the learning curve and empowering users to initiate projects quickly and correctly. By leveraging templates from successful past projects, the Joule agent also helps ensure that new projects are set up consistently and in compliance with your company's standards right from the start. We are currently running a beta program for this and encourage you to get involved! Register for the Customer Engagement Initiative via this landing page as of March 15, 2026.

 

Figure 5: The AI-powered solution assists users in rapidly setting up projects by leveraging similar past projects when the volume is high, and projects are repetitive in nature.



Other innovations in Enterprise Portfolio and Project Management

We know how critical it is to have a clear, unified view of project financials. That's why we’ve introduced the company code currency into the Project Cost report. Now, you can see a consolidated view of all your key cost figures including planned costs, actuals, commitments, and even project stock costs – all in a single, consistent currency. This provides a much clearer picture of your project's overall financial health and variance.

There is one important prerequisite to keep in mind: for the report to display in the company code currency, all the projects and WBS elements you select for that report must share the same company code. This ensures data integrity and accurate reporting. For a more detailed guide on this feature, I encourage you to check out the documentation on the SAP Help Portal.

Second, we’ve Improved system usability by segregating the profitability segment from settlement rules for clearer allocation and analysis. What does this mean for you? In the past, assigning profitability might have required you to set up a settlement rule. Now, for projects with revenue, you can assign the profitability segment directly to a billing WBS element using the "Assign" function. This is a much more direct and intuitive workflow. It saves you steps, simplifies the allocation process, and makes your analysis clearer and more efficient. As with all our features, you can find comprehensive details on this enhancement in the SAP Help Portal.

Finally, and this is something I’m personally very excited about, we are going beyond system features to build a stronger community. We are officially introducing the new CIP community – a collaborative space designed for our customers, partners, and SAP experts to connect. The goal is to build a powerful network where we can all share ideas, discuss best practices, and co-innovate on the future of enterprise and collaborative project scenarios. This is your platform to influence the direction of our products and learn from your peers.

If you are interested in joining this community and helping shape the future of project management at SAP, please reach out to my colleagues, Anke Junker anke.junker@sap.com or Varsha Chetan Manu varsha.chetan.manu@sap.com, to get involved.


The SAP Cloud ERP 2602 release for EPPM is all about making your project management more connected, automated, and intelligent. From ensuring a single source of truth to simplifying daily tasks for every project role, these innovations are designed to deliver tangible business value and set you up for success.

Thank you for your time, and I look forward to seeing how you leverage these new capabilities.

entry.title: Product Compliance in SAP Cloud ERP 2602
entry.content:
Welcome to your one-stop shop to learn and share knowledge about SAP's ready-to-run public cloud ERP software solution.  

 SAP Cloud ERP is part of SAP Business Suite that brings AI, data, and applications together into a fully integrated system. This community is open for anyone in the cloud ERP ecosystem–customers, partners, and SAP experts.  

 

In this blog post I’d like to outline the innovations for SAP Cloud ERP 2602 Release in the area of Product Compliance. These are the topics that are covered:

Safety Data Sheet and Label Management

  • Extension of safety data sheet (SDS) generation (7DO)
  • SDS management and shipment with branded products with specific data for final SDS generation (3VR)
  • Definition of a fallback SDS for a product (3VQ)

 Dangerous Goods Management

  • Support for multi-component products that contain two or more dangerous goods (3FC)

 

In case you do not need all the information below and briefly want to get an overview of the release highlights, please watch this video with the top four key innovations:

Video#1: SAP Cloud ERP 2602 for Product Compliance

 

Extension of safety data sheet (SDS) generation



Business Background
To maintain compliance, it is crucial that Safety Data Sheets (SDS) reflect the latest regulatory requirements and clearly communicate any updates to recipients. This includes providing more granular information in specific sections, such as handling and storage, and highlighting changes between document versions for better transparency.

Key Features
This innovation improves the SDS generation process for regulatory assessments, incorporating updated requirements for Section 7 (Handling and Storage) and Section 15 (Regulatory Information). It is now possible to include vertical change marks in the final SDS, which visually indicate all data that has been modified since the last released version, ensuring changes are easily identifiable. Additionally, the GHS classification has been enhanced to allow for the maintenance of the index number and annex name, which will be included as output on the SDS.

 

 

Video#2: Demo Extension of safety data sheet (SDS) generation



SDS management and shipment with branded products with specific data for final SDS generation



Business Background
Companies often market the same base product under different brand names, each with unique compliance obligations for the specific markets in which they are sold. It is essential to manage market-specific data, such as Poison Centre Notification (PCN) details like the Unique Formula Identifier (UFI), and ensure this information is correctly represented on the SDS for that branded product.

Key Features
This innovation allows you to apply specific compliance purposes to branded products, determining which data is relevant for the markets where the product is sold. The system now supports compliance requirement versions for the Poison Centre Notification, enabling you to manage the registration status and UFI number for a branded product. When an SDS is generated and shipped, this UFI number is now automatically included on the final document.

 


Video#3: Demo SDS management and shipment with branded products with specific data for final SDS generation

 

Definition of a fallback SDS for a product



Business Background
In scenarios where a product is shipped to a country without a specific, locally compliant SDS being available, the shipment process could previously fail, causing delays. To prevent these interruptions, businesses need a contingency to provide a standard, alternative SDS, ensuring that at least some safety information is shared with the customer and the shipment can proceed.

Key Features
You can now define a global fallback SDS within the system by activating it for a specific compliance requirement, such as "German SDS in English." If the system does not find a released, country-specific SDS for a product during shipment, it automatically uses this predefined fallback document. This feature helps to minimize shipment errors and ensures that customers receive critical safety information, even if it is not in the 100% correct local format.

 


Video#4: Demo Definition of a fallback SDS for a product

 

Support for multi-component products that contain two or more dangerous goods



Business Background
Products that are sold as a single unit but consist of multiple components (e.g., a two-part glue kit) present a challenge for dangerous goods management. Classifying each component individually is often insufficient, as regulations may require classifying the entire kit as a single entity to ensure compliant handling, checks, and documentation throughout the logistics process.

Key Features
This feature integrates the processing of multi-component products directly into the existing dangerous goods framework, allowing for classification at the product header level. Users can now classify the entire multi-component product, define packaging details for the kit, and assign relevant enclosure variants for transport. This ensures that dangerous goods checks in sales and delivery processes are executed correctly on the main product, not the individual components.

 

 

Video#5: Support for multi-component products that contain two or more dangerous goods

entry.title: Driving adoption by structuring the current available content for SAP Contract and Lease Management
entry.content:
In an environment where organizations juggle complex supplier relationships, diverse lease portfolios, and evolving accounting standards, moving contract and lease management to the public cloud is no longer a nice-to-have—it is a strategic imperative. Cloud delivery accelerates time to value, embeds compliance such as IFRS 16 and ASC842 directly into daily operations, and seamlessly connects contract data with sourcing, procurement, finance, and asset management. SAP Contract and Lease Management, particularly within SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition, supports both real estate leases—such as land and buildings—and non–real estate leases, including car fleets, machinery, technical equipment, and other movable assets. By managing valuation, accounting, and postings for both portfolios in a single integrated solution, organizations achieve stronger governance, lower risk, and better, insight-driven decision-making across their entire lease landscape.

As SAP’s Contact and Lease Management is a core functionality that enables further possibilities, it makes sense to structure both the currently available content and future additions. As the topic and its content will continue to grow, I would like to introduce an organizational approach to cluster new content. This will help new joiners and beginners, as well as advanced users, to quickly understand which content areas will be covered going forward.

Further the content should be named with the following naming convention.

  • SAP Contract and Lease Management Process Details: Title
  • SAP Contract and Lease Management E2E: Title
  • SAP Contract and Lease Management Product & strategy updates: Title
  • SAP Contract and Lease Management Architecture: Title

 

 

I propose the following structure. The sections below explain when each category should be used.

  • Process Details
    Use this section when a blog explains specific steps or details of a process. This may include information about individual tiles or the handling of subprocesses.
  • Architecture
    Use this section for topics related to the architecture of Contract and Lease Management, including system design and integration aspects.
  • Product and strategy updates
    Use this section to share product-related information such as new features, release updates, or hotfixes provided by Product Management for Contract and Lease Management. This section also includes product strategy.
  • E2E
    This section offers a broader, end-to-end view of SAP Contract and Lease Management, focusing on overall concepts and best practices.

Below is a selected list of useful SAP blogs related to Contract and Lease Management.
This list is not exhaustive and can be expanded over time.

E2E

  1. The article is about how SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition handles lease accounting to comply with international standards like IFRS 16 and ASC 842.

Three main aspects of the blog:

  • It automates lessee and lessor accounting processes, including calculations for Right-of-Use assets, liabilities, and periodic postings.
  • The solution supports both IFRS 16 and ASC 842 standards, including exemptions for short-term and low-value leases.
  • It integrates with the Universal Journal for transparency and uses a clean-core approach to simplify compliance and audits.

Source: Cutting Through the Complexity: Lease Accounting i... - SAP Community

  1. The blog explains SAP Contract and Lease Management in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition and how it supports lease accounting under IFRS16 and other standards.

The three most important aspects, see below:

  • SAP Contract and Lease Management provides tools and best practices to manage lease-in, lease-out, and sublease contracts, including valuation and periodic postings for IFRS, US GAAP, and local GAAP.
  • It enables contract creation, mass migration, valuation, and adjustments through dedicated apps, ensuring compliance and automation of financial postings.
  • The solution integrates with Finance and Asset Accounting, offering reporting capabilities and a standardized approach for companies moving from custom systems to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition.

Source: CLM in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud - SAP Community

The difference between the two is as follows:
The first summary focuses on lease accounting functionality in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition, explaining how the system automates lessee and lessor processes and supports IFRS 16 and ASC 842.
The second summary takes a broader process-oriented approach, covering contract creation, migration, valuation, and reporting.

Architecture

  1. The blog is about SAP’s approach to real estate management architecture and solution options within the SAP Intelligent Suite.

The three most important aspects, see below:

  • It explains key business capabilities like property, workspace, and occupancy management, along with compliance for financial leases under IFRS16.
  • The article compares solution options: SAP S/4HANA for Contract, Lease and Real Estate Management (RE-FX), SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition Contract and Lease Management, and the new Planon Real Estate Management partnership.
  • SAP Cloud for Real Estate is being phased out, and SAP Real Estate and Facilities Management by Planon is positioned as the future target architecture for comprehensive real estate management.

Explanation: SAP Real Estate and Facilities Management by Planon together with SAP Contract and Lease Management is SAPs “got-to” solution for commercial and corporate real estate business processes. Core functionality to support Real Estate and Facility Management requirements is in SAP Contract and Lease Management.

Source: Architecture Decisions for Real Estate Management - SAP Community

 

Release and strategy updates

    These are the latest releases updates for Finance. There is a chapter for Contract and Lease in each blog.

entry.title: Using Custom Logic in SAP S/4HANA Cloud to change field status of Purchase Requisition
entry.content:
Problem Background:

We received a customer request: when creating a purchase requisition, they want the Valuation Price field to be optional, but in the current system this field is mandatory.

Solution:

Attempt to meet the requirement through custom logic using a BAdI.

Analysis Steps:

1. After searching in SAP for Me, we found a KBA 3322867 - Valuation Price field is mandatory in Create Purchase Requisitions app - SAP for Me which provides a solution to this problem. So we can try to use BAdI MM_PUR_S4_PR_ FLDCNTRL_SIMPLE to solve this problem.

2. We enter APP Custom Logic to create an implementation. The description of this BAdI is "Change of Field Control for Purchase Requisitions". In the documentation, we can get more information including supported fields. "PURCHASEREQUISITIONPRICE - Valuation Price" is included, that means our requirement can be fulfilled by this BAdI.

3. With this BAdI, we can set four status for supported fields of Purchase Requisition: Hidden, Read-only, Mandatory, Optional.

  • '-': To hide the field
  • '*': To make the field read-only
  • '+': To make the field mandatory
  • '.': To make the field optional

4. The sample code of this BAdI is quite readable and easy. Based on this problem, implement the BAdI. The specific code is as follows.

FIELD-SYMBOLS <fs> TYPE mmpur_s_pr_fldsel.

READ TABLE fieldselection_table ASSIGNING <fs> WITH KEY field = 'PURCHASEREQUISITIONPRICE'.
IF sy-subrc EQ 0.
    <fs>-fieldstatus = '.'.
ENDIF.

5. After testing, the BAdI works prefect. This BAdI not only supports GUI APP - Create Purchase Requisition - Advanced, but also supports Fiori APP - Manage Purchase Requisitions - Professional.

Conclusion:

By reading this article and several previous blogs on similar scenarios, I hope you now understand how to use custom logic to apply certain restrictions when creating preliminary invoices for purchase orders.
